LIFE402M
Notes
This module is due to commence in Jan 2025

The module is being developed into a 15 credit module from a 7.5 credit module (this was already at M level) in order for the module to still be taken by the MChem students following a Year 4 curriculum review in Chemistry which has involved the removal of 7.5 credit modules. This has been achieved by increasing the number of lectures, the addition of two tutorials, increasing the volume of additional online material the students need to engage with, adding a learning outcome, and increasing the word count for the assessments to allow the greater breadth and depth of material to be included.

Students within Chemistry have been consulted on the removal of 7.5 credit module and associated changes. Changes have also been through out Board of Studies which also has student representation.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials covering the hallmarks of cancer and cancer aetiology through to cancer treatment from early chemotherapy to modern molecular targeted therapy. Students will also learn about the the evaluation of the cost-effectiveness of anti-cancer drugs and the design of cancer clinical trials.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
Prerequisite modules are LIFE206 Drug Action and LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of current understanding of cancer development and progression, and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer;

To explain the latest knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects and drug resistance;

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of modern cancer drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of cancer development and progression and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects, drug toxicity and drug resistance. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two  summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in cancer biology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture title and theme

1 Introduction: Hallmarks of Cancer Dr. Mike Cross (MJC) - Introduction to the seminal work of Douglas Hanahan and Robert Weinberg in characterising the different hallmarks of cancer cells.

2 The Aetiology of Cancer & Cancer Treatment (MJC) – Analysis of cancer incidence, cancer classification and causes of cancer

3 Cancer Genetics Lekh Dahal (LD)- The role of oncogenes and tumour suppressor genes

4 Gene Therapy (LD)- Genetic disease and the use of gene therapy

5 Cell Cycle and Cancer I (LD)- Introduction to cell division and regulation of the cell cycle

6 Cell Cycle and Cancer II (LD)- The cell cycle and oncogenic transformation in pancreatic cancer

7 Modulating Cancer Cell Death Dr. Fiona Healy (FH)- Apoptosis and the regulation of cell death

8 Cancer Chemotherapy I FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

9 Cancer Chemotherapy II FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

10 Mechanisms of Drug Resistance FH- Molecular mechanism of cancer cell resistance to classical chemotherapy drugs

11 Kinase Inhibitors I Dr. Anil Mondru (AM)- Introduction to protein phosphorylation and protein kinases. Development of Glivec and the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML).

12 Kinase Inhibitors II AM- Classification of leukaemia and the use of kinase inhibitors to treat AML

13 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Oestrogen receptor-mediated cancer & modulators Dr. Lawrence Barrera (LB)- Introduction to steroid hormone action and inhibitors of oestrogen action.

14 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Androgen & Progesterone receptors & modulators LB- Prostate cancer and inhibitors of androgens

15 Angiogenesis and Tumour Hypoxia MJC- Introduction to the role of blood vessels in cancer progression and the role of hypoxia.

16 Angiogenesis Inhibitors MJC- Development of angiogenesis inhibitors and their clinical impact

17 Cancer Immunotherapy I MJC- Introduction to the role of the immune system in suppressing cancer development.

18 Cancer Immunotherapy II Dr. Anna Olsson-Brown- Development and clinical impact of immune checkpoint inhibitors

19 Molecular Toxicology of anti-cancer agents MJC- Analysis of preclinical screens to detect anti-cancer drug cardiovascular toxicity and the molecular toxicity of anthracycline drugs.

20 Future Cancer Therapy MJC- Introduction to personalised cancer medicine to target specific mutations in cancer patients.

This builds on LIFE206 knowledge around how the signal transduction pathways can be modulated to enhance cancer therapy and knowledge of the regulatory framework underlying the testing and approval of drugs. It builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework

In a typical week, students will experience synchronous and asynchronous delivery of materials.

Teaching method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (20 x 1 hr lectures)

Teaching method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and around the assessments.
Session 1 - the cost and evaluation of anti-cancer drugs. Dr. Mike Cross.
Session 2 - design of clinical trials. Dr. Richard Jackson. Liverpool Clinical Trials Unit

Teaching method 3 (128 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions. This will include materials on hallmarks of cancer. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 2000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so it can be applied to Cycle 2. Whole class feedback sessions are ran in Week 9 in advance of detailed individual feedback being released to better facilitate this.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 40%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

 IM4 Explain the mechanisms of drug-resistance to anti-cancer therapies
 IM5 ​Critically analyse and explain scientific literature and clinical data regarding the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of anti-cancer therapy in patients;

Replace Instances with Code
LIFE402M
Notes
This module is due to commence in Jan 2025

The module is being developed into a 15 credit module from a 7.5 credit module (this was already at M level) in order for the module to still be taken by the MChem students following a Year 4 curriculum review in Chemistry which has involved the removal of 7.5 credit modules. This has been achieved by increasing the number of lectures, the addition of two tutorials, increasing the volume of additional online material the students need to engage with, adding a learning outcome, and increasing the word count for the assessments to allow the greater breadth and depth of material to be included.

Students within Chemistry have been consulted on the removal of 7.5 credit module and associated changes. Changes have also been through out Board of Studies which also has student representation.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials covering the hallmarks of cancer and cancer aetiology through to cancer treatment from early chemotherapy to modern molecular targeted therapy. Students will also learn about the the evaluation of the cost-effectiveness of anti-cancer drugs and the design of cancer clinical trials.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
Prerequisite modules are LIFE206 Drug Action and LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of current understanding of cancer development and progression, and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer;

To explain the latest knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects and drug resistance;

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of modern cancer drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of cancer development and progression and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects, drug toxicity and drug resistance. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two  summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in cancer biology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture title and theme

1 Introduction: Hallmarks of Cancer Dr. Mike Cross (MJC) - Introduction to the seminal work of Douglas Hanahan and Robert Weinberg in characterising the different hallmarks of cancer cells.

2 The Aetiology of Cancer & Cancer Treatment (MJC) – Analysis of cancer incidence, cancer classification and causes of cancer

3 Cancer Genetics Lekh Dahal (LD)- The role of oncogenes and tumour suppressor genes

4 Gene Therapy (LD)- Genetic disease and the use of gene therapy

5 Cell Cycle and Cancer I (LD)- Introduction to cell division and regulation of the cell cycle

6 Cell Cycle and Cancer II (LD)- The cell cycle and oncogenic transformation in pancreatic cancer

7 Modulating Cancer Cell Death Dr. Fiona Healy (FH)- Apoptosis and the regulation of cell death

8 Cancer Chemotherapy I FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

9 Cancer Chemotherapy II FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

10 Mechanisms of Drug Resistance FH- Molecular mechanism of cancer cell resistance to classical chemotherapy drugs

11 Kinase Inhibitors I Dr. Anil Mondru (AM)- Introduction to protein phosphorylation and protein kinases. Development of Glivec and the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML).

12 Kinase Inhibitors II AM- Classification of leukaemia and the use of kinase inhibitors to treat AML

13 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Oestrogen receptor-mediated cancer & modulators Dr. Lawrence Barrera (LB)- Introduction to steroid hormone action and inhibitors of oestrogen action.

14 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Androgen & Progesterone receptors & modulators LB- Prostate cancer and inhibitors of androgens

15 Angiogenesis and Tumour Hypoxia MJC- Introduction to the role of blood vessels in cancer progression and the role of hypoxia.

16 Angiogenesis Inhibitors MJC- Development of angiogenesis inhibitors and their clinical impact

17 Cancer Immunotherapy I MJC- Introduction to the role of the immune system in suppressing cancer development.

18 Cancer Immunotherapy II Dr. Anna Olsson-Brown- Development and clinical impact of immune checkpoint inhibitors

19 Molecular Toxicology of anti-cancer agents MJC- Analysis of preclinical screens to detect anti-cancer drug cardiovascular toxicity and the molecular toxicity of anthracycline drugs.

20 Future Cancer Therapy MJC- Introduction to personalised cancer medicine to target specific mutations in cancer patients.

This builds on LIFE206 knowledge around how the signal transduction pathways can be modulated to enhance cancer therapy and knowledge of the regulatory framework underlying the testing and approval of drugs. It builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework

In a typical week, students will experience synchronous and asynchronous delivery of materials.

Teaching method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (20 x 1 hr lectures)

Teaching method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and around the assessments.
Session 1 - the cost and evaluation of anti-cancer drugs. Dr. Mike Cross.
Session 2 - design of clinical trials. Dr. Richard Jackson. Liverpool Clinical Trials Unit

Teaching method 3 (128 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions. This will include materials on hallmarks of cancer. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 2000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so it can be applied to Cycle 2. Whole class feedback sessions are ran in Week 9 in advance of detailed individual feedback being released to better facilitate this.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 40%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

 ReferenceOutcome 
 IM1 Critically appraise, the pathophysiological process of cancer development and progression;

 IM4 Explain the mechanisms of drug-resistance to anti-cancer therapies
 IM5 ​Critically analyse and explain scientific literature and clinical data regarding the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of anti-cancer therapy in patients;
 IM6 ​Utilise information to synthesise conclusions, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills gained during the module.
 IM7 Critically evaluate structure activity relationships through analysis of structural changes and trends in biological activity.

Overview

Overview
This module will be delivered by a series of lectures and tutorials covering the hallmarks of cancer and cancer aetiology through to cancer treatment from early chemotherapy to modern molecular targeted therapy. Students will also learn about the the evaluation of the cost-effectiveness of anti-cancer drugs and the design of cancer clinical trials.

The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions.

The module will be assessed by two summative exercises including data interpretation and analysis.
Prerequisite modules are LIFE206 Drug Action and LIFE207 Principles of Pharmacology
Educational Aims
To provide an explanation of current understanding of cancer development and progression, and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer;

To explain the latest knowledge of the molecular mechanisms of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects and drug resistance;

To give students an awareness of the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of modern cancer drugs.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide an understanding of cancer development and progression and how this is exploited in the rational design of drugs to target cancer. A further aim is to explain the molecular mechanism of anti-cancer drugs and the potential for side-effects, drug toxicity and drug resistance. Materials will be delivered through a series of lectures and tutorials. The module will be delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence. Students will critically evaluate scientific literature and clinical data, synthesise information, critically review evidence to support conclusions, and define complex problems by applying appropriate knowledge and skills. Problem solving, critical thinking, creativity will be utilised in analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. The module will be assessed by two  summative exercise. The module would be taken by students with a keen interest in cancer biology and medicinal chemistry.
Outline Syllabus
Lecture title and theme

1 Introduction: Hallmarks of Cancer Dr. Mike Cross (MJC) - Introduction to the seminal work of Douglas Hanahan and Robert Weinberg in characterising the different hallmarks of cancer cells.

2 The Aetiology of Cancer & Cancer Treatment (MJC) – Analysis of cancer incidence, cancer classification and causes of cancer

3 Cancer Genetics Lekh Dahal (LD)- The role of oncogenes and tumour suppressor genes

4 Gene Therapy (LD)- Genetic disease and the use of gene therapy

5 Cell Cycle and Cancer I (LD)- Introduction to cell division and regulation of the cell cycle

6 Cell Cycle and Cancer II (LD)- The cell cycle and oncogenic transformation in pancreatic cancer

7 Modulating Cancer Cell Death Dr. Fiona Healy (FH)- Apoptosis and the regulation of cell death

8 Cancer Chemotherapy I FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

9 Cancer Chemotherapy II FH- Introduction to classical chemotherapy drugs

10 Mechanisms of Drug Resistance FH- Molecular mechanism of cancer cell resistance to classical chemotherapy drugs

11 Kinase Inhibitors I Dr. Anil Mondru (AM)- Introduction to protein phosphorylation and protein kinases. Development of Glivec and the treatment of chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML).

12 Kinase Inhibitors II AM- Classification of leukaemia and the use of kinase inhibitors to treat AML

13 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Oestrogen receptor-mediated cancer & modulators Dr. Lawrence Barrera (LB)- Introduction to steroid hormone action and inhibitors of oestrogen action.

14 Hormone Regulated Cancer: Androgen & Progesterone receptors & modulators LB- Prostate cancer and inhibitors of androgens

15 Angiogenesis and Tumour Hypoxia MJC- Introduction to the role of blood vessels in cancer progression and the role of hypoxia.

16 Angiogenesis Inhibitors MJC- Development of angiogenesis inhibitors and their clinical impact

17 Cancer Immunotherapy I MJC- Introduction to the role of the immune system in suppressing cancer development.

18 Cancer Immunotherapy II Dr. Anna Olsson-Brown- Development and clinical impact of immune checkpoint inhibitors

19 Molecular Toxicology of anti-cancer agents MJC- Analysis of preclinical screens to detect anti-cancer drug cardiovascular toxicity and the molecular toxicity of anthracycline drugs.

20 Future Cancer Therapy MJC- Introduction to personalised cancer medicine to target specific mutations in cancer patients.

This builds on LIFE206 knowledge around how the signal transduction pathways can be modulated to enhance cancer therapy and knowledge of the regulatory framework underlying the testing and approval of drugs. It builds on the broader content covered in LIFE207 around understanding of the quantitative aspects of drug action, the relationship between drug efficacy and chemical structure, pharmacokinetics, drug concentration and response.

Library resources will be accessible through the module reading list, other key learning resources will accessible through VLE, Canvas. All journal articles are either Open Access or available as PDF's through Canvas.

Students are provided with reading material ahead of the lectures and are expected to read all resources on the reading list in order to complete the assessments and tutorials. Supplementary resources are encouraged for the assessments. Pre-tutorial material will be released in order to help them complete the tutorial.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching in this module are designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (‘Research-connected teaching’, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Delivery methods may include flipped classrooms, polling, and discussions based on pre-lecture reading or recordings etc. These engage and challenge students in an active learning process, and coupled with independent learning, will build self-confidence (Liverpool Curriculum Framework

In a typical week, students will experience synchronous and asynchronous delivery of materials.

Teaching method 1: Synchronous F2F lectures (20 x 1 hr lectures)

Teaching method 2: Online asynchronous tutorial (2 x 1 hr) - These will take place at suitable points after delivery of the relevant F2F material and around the assessments.
Session 1 - the cost and evaluation of anti-cancer drugs. Dr. Mike Cross.
Session 2 - design of clinical trials. Dr. Richard Jackson. Liverpool Clinical Trials Unit

Teaching method 3 (128 hrs): Self-directed learning aided by directed reading and formative questions. This will include materials on hallmarks of cancer. A list of reading material, from scientific papers to book chapters, will be provided for students at the end of each lecture to support their learning and progression through the course.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessments reflect real-life and career-based scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework). Students will interpret scientific data and complete a written assessment that combines problem solving with synthesis of research-led materials.

Assessment cycle-I will be a 1500 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 40% and occur following the first cycle of teaching in week 6 to 8.

Assessment cycle-II will be a 2000 word written assignment that involves data interpretation/essay. This will be worth 60% and occur at the end of the course in week 11 to 13 in May.

Feedback from Cycle 1 is received within 3 weeks so it can be applied to Cycle 2. Whole class feedback sessions are ran in Week 9 in advance of detailed individual feedback being released to better facilitate this.

Reassessment strategy: there is a resit opportunity. The format of the assessments will be very similar but different questions will be employed. This will take place in the normal reassessment window and be capped at 40%. The resit in the summer covers both cycle I and cycle II. Failure of cycle I assessment does not impact ability to sit the cycle II assessment as different content is involved. The standard CoPA penalty for late submission applies.

Assessment is anonymous and submitted through Canvas the VLE which allows anonymous submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Prior LIFE modules in earlier years prepare students for the submissions therefore no draft opportunity is given, as is standard through all LIFE cycled assessments. Following assessment release they have 1 week to ask any questions relating to the assessment.

Notes
This module is due to commence in Jan 2025

The module is being developed into a 15 credit module from a 7.5 credit module (this was already at M level) in order for the module to still be taken by the MChem students following a Year 4 curriculum review in Chemistry which has involved the removal of 7.5 credit modules. This has been achieved by increasing the number of lectures, the addition of two tutorials, increasing the volume of additional online material the students need to engage with, adding a learning outcome, and increasing the word count for the assessments to allow the greater breadth and depth of material to be included.

Students within Chemistry have been consulted on the removal of 7.5 credit module and associated changes. Changes have also been through out Board of Studies which also has student representation.
